facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 801 of 1963 is an appeal by special leave from the judgment and decree dated September 2, 1959 of the Madras High Court in Second Appeal No. 774 of 1957.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 801 of 1963. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and decree dated September 2, 1959 of the Madras High Court in Second Appeal No. 774 of 1957.

facts.text: The properties involved are agricultural lands situated in Eragudi village, Musiri taluk, Tiruchirappalli district.

anchor.surface_text: The properties involved in the suit companysist of agricultural lands situated in Eragudi village, Musiri taluk, Tiruchirappalli district.

facts.text: The appellants claim the lands were granted in Inam to the ancestor of Ambalathadum Pachai Kandai Udayavar by the Carnatic Rulers before British power.

anchor.surface_text: According to the appellants, the said lands had been granted in Inam to the ancestor of one Ambalathadum Pachai Kandai Udayavar by the Carnatic Rulers before the advent of the British power in India.

facts.text: Inam title deeds were issued in favour of the family of Pachai Kandai Udayavar in the sixties of the last century during Inam settlement.

anchor.surface_text: The original grantdeeds are number available but at the time of the settlement of the Inams in the sixties of the last century, Inam title deeds were issued in favour of the family of Pachai Kandai Udayavar.

facts.text: The properties were granted burdened with obligation of performing services in a Matam and were alienated, entitling appellants.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants averred that the properties companyered by the grant bad been granted in Inam to the original grantee burdened with the obligation of performing certain services in a Matam. The said properties were alienated from time to time, and as a result of the last alienation, the appellants became entitled to them.

facts.text: Respondents 1 to 3 claim to be trustees of Pachai Kandai Udayavar Temple at Eragudi.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants in the present litigation claimed a declaration about their title to the properties in suit and a permanent injunction restraining respondents 1 to 3, who claimed to be the trustees of an alleged Pachai Kandai Udayavar Temple at Eragudi, from interfering with their possession of the same.

facts.text: Respondent No. 4, Deputy Commissioner, Hindu Religious and Charitable Endowments, Tiruchirappalli, appointed respondents 1 to 3 as trustees on 7th March, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: Respondent No. 4 is the Deputy Commissioner, Hindu Religious and Charitable Endowments, L9Sup. CI/66 9 Tiruchirappalli, and he has been impleaded because he has purported to appoint respondents 1 to 3 as trustees of the said alleged Temple on the 7th March, 1951.

facts.text: Suit No. 103 of 1954 instituted on 13th September, 1954 under S. 87 of Madras Hindu Religious and Charitable Endowments Act 1951 in District Munsif Court at Turaiyur.

anchor.surface_text: This suit  No. 103 of 1954  was instituted on the 13th September, 1954, under S. 87 of the, Madras Hindu Religious and Charitable Endowments Act  No. XIX of 1951   hereinafter called the Act , in the Court of the District Munsif at Turaiyur.

facts.text: Respondents 1-3 obtained certificate from Resp4 that properties belong to Temple and filed application under s.87 before Magistrate for possession.

anchor.surface_text: Respondents 1 to 3 who have been appointed as trustees of the said temple by respondent No. 4, obtained a certificate from him that the properties in question belonged to the Temple and on the basis of the said certificate, they had filed an application before the Magistrate having jurisdiction in the area under s. 87 of the Act for possession.

facts.text: Magistrate overruled appellants' title claim and directed delivery of possession to Resp 1-3.

anchor.surface_text: Notice of this application was served on the appellants and they pleaded their own title to the properties. The Magistrate, however, over-ruled the claim made by the appellants and directed them to deliver possession of the properties to respondents 1 to 3.

facts.text: Trial court decreed appellants' suit on 14th February, 1955, holding grant personal Inam, not religious endowment, title proved, prescription upheld.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, the appellants suit was decreed on the 14th February, 1955. Respondents 1 to 3 preferred an appeal  No. 129 of 1955  in the Court of the Subordinate Judge at Tiruchirappalli, challenging the companyrectness of the said decree.

facts.text: Lower appellate court dismissed Resp 1-3 appeal No. 129/1955 on March 29, 1957, no temple proved, prescription title established.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal preferred by respondents 1 to 3, therefore, failed and was dismissed with companyts on March 29, 1957.

facts.text: Madras High Court in Second Appeal No. 774/1957 partly allowed Resp appeal on Sept 2, 1959, holding properties belong to Temple, some alienations barred by Art 134B.

anchor.surface_text: This judgment was pronounced on the 2nd September, 1959. It is against this decision that the appellants have companye to this Court by special leave.

facts.text: Alienation under Ext. A-2 in 1914 covers items 1,2, part 3,7,8, portion well item 5, outside Art 134B.

anchor.surface_text: Thus companysidered, the alienations in regard to items 1, 2, part of item 3, items 7 8, and a portion of the well in item 5 sold under Ext. A-2 in 1914 were held to be outside the mischief of Art. 134B.

facts.text: Items 4 and part item 6 sold in auction 1927 under Exts A-7 A-8, outside Art 134B as auction sales.

anchor.surface_text: Similarly, item 4 and a part of item 6 which had been sold in auction in execution of a decree in 1927  vide Exts. A-7 and A-8 , were also held to be outside the scope of Art. 134-B, because the said article does number companyer auction sales.

facts.text: Alienations Exts A-3 (7 Oct 1917), A-6 (2 Jul 1926), A-12 (2 Jul 1926) held within Art 134B by HC.

anchor.surface_text: That left the alienations companyered by Exts. A-3, A-6 and A- 12 to be companysidered. These three alienations were effected on the 7th October, 1917, 2nd July, 1926, and 2nd July, 1926 respectively.

facts.text: Respondents contend properties granted to Pachai Kandai Udayavar Temple.

anchor.surface_text: Respondents 1 to 3 resisted this suit and companytended that the properties in suit had number been granted to the predecessor of Pachai Kandai Udayavar as alleged by the appellants. Their case was that the said properties had been granted to the Pachai Kandai Udayavar Temple and formed part of its properties.

facts.text: Pachaikandaswamiar (transferor) left village more than 25 years before suit, resigned or removed from management.

anchor.surface_text: Raju lyer, who was examined as a witness by the appellants, stated that he and Amirthalinga lyer had been performing the worship of the temple for the past 27 years, and he added that the alienor and his son had left the village more than 25 years ago

facts.text: Notice on 19th June 1948 by Assistant Commissioner stated no legally constituted trustees for Temple, mismanaged.

anchor.surface_text: Besides, when respondents 1 to 3 were appointed as trustees of the temple, a numberice was issued by the office of Assistant Commissioner for Hindu Religious Endowments, Tiruchirappalli, on the 19th June, 1948, in which it was specifically averred that there were numberlegally companystituted trustees for Sri Pachaikantha Udayavar Temple, Eragudi, and it was mismanaged

facts.text: Supreme Court holds alienor removed from management more than 12 years before suit, Art 134B limitation expired, restores lower appellate decree.

anchor.surface_text: On that view of the matter, we must hold that the trial Judge and the lower appellate Court were right in decreeing the appellants suit in its entirety. We must accordingly set aside the decree passed by the High Court in regard to the transfers companyered by Exts. A-3, A-6 and A-12, and restore that of the lower appellate Court.
Appeal by special leave from the judgment and decree dated September 2, 1959 of the Madras High Court in Second Appeal No. 774 of 1957.

anchor.surface_text: He contends that Art. 134-B would not apply to the present case, because the alienations evidenced by Exts. A-3, A-6 and A-12 show that the alienors purported to transfer the properties not as Poojaris or managers of a temple, but in their individual character as owners of the said properties. Such a case falls outside the purview of Art. 134-B and must be governed by Art. 144 of the First Schedule to the Limitation Act.

The original grantdeeds are number available but at the time of the settlement of the Inams in the sixties of the last century, Inam title deeds were issued in favour of the family of Pachai Kandai Udayavar. The appellants averred that the properties companyered by the grant bad been granted in Inam to the original grantee burdened with the obligation of performing certain services in a Matam. The said properties were alienated from time to time, and as a result of the last alienation, the appellants became entitled to them.

holdings.text: Article 134-B applies to all cases where it is shown that the immovable property was comprised in the endowment and that it has been transferred by a previous manager for a valuable consideration; the character of the representations made by the previous manager in regard to his relation with the property is irrelevant for the purpose of Art. 134-B.

anchor.surface_text: Confining ourselves to the first column of Art. 134-B at this stage, the question which we have to decide is does this article permit any distinction to be made between transfers effected by a previous manager on the basis that the property transferred belongs to the religious endowment, and those made by him on the basis that the said property is his own private property ?

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual interpretation of column 1 of Art. 134-B requires proof of three facts only: property in endowment, transfer by previous manager, for valuable consideration; no requirement regarding transferor's representations about ownership.

holdings.text: Article 134-B applies to all cases where it is shown that the immovable property was comprised in the endowment and that it has been transferred by a previous manager for a valuable consideration; the character of the representations made by the previous manager in regard to his relation with the property is irrelevant for the purpose of Art. 134-B.

anchor.surface_text: Confining ourselves to the first column of Art. 134-B at this stage, the question which we have to decide is does this article permit any distinction to be made between transfers effected by a previous manager on the basis that the property transferred belongs to the religious endowment, and those made by him on the basis that the said property is his own private property ?

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual interpretation of column 1 of Art. 134-B requires proof of three facts only: property in endowment, transfer by previous manager, for valuable consideration; no requirement regarding transferor's representations about ownership.

holdings.text: On the findings recorded by the High Court, it is clear that the properties belonged to the temple, that they have been transferred by persons who must be deemed to be the previous managers of the temple and that they have been transferred for valuable consideration; all the ingredients prescribed by the first column of Art. 134-B are satisfied.

anchor.surface_text: On the findings recorded by the High Court, it is clear that the properties belonged to the temple that they have been transferred by persons who must be deemed to be the previous managers of the temple and that they have been transferred for valuable consideration. The present suit has been brought against respondents 1 to 3 who are appointed trustees of the temple by respondent No. 4 and so, all the ingredients prescribed by the first column of Art. 134-B are satisfied.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Accepting High Court's factual findings that properties part of temple endowment transferred by previous managers for value, satisfying Art. 134-B requirements.

holdings.text: All the facts clearly show that the alienor disposed of all the property and left the village and that for the last 25 years or so, the management has been taken over by other persons who are acting as de facto managers of the temple; the alienor had been removed from management more than 12 years before the suit.

anchor.surface_text: all the facts [...] clearly show not only that the alienor disposed of all the property and left the village but also that for the last 25 years or so, the management has been taken over by other persons who are acting as de facto managers of the temple.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Oral evidence of witnesses that alienor left village >25 years ago, sold all properties, no participation in worship; others performed pooja and managed as de facto managers >25 years; 1948 notice confirms no constituted trustees.

holdings.text: If a suit were brought by respondents 1 to 3 on the date when they were appointed trustees by respondent No. 4, it would be barred under Art. 134-B; the trial Judge and the lower appellate Court were right in decreeing the appellants' suit in its entirety.

anchor.surface_text: On that view of the matter, we must hold that the trial Judge and the lower appellate Court were right in decreeing the appellants suit in its entirety. We must accordingly set aside the decree passed by the High Court in regard to the transfers covered by Exts. A-3, A-6 and A-12, and restore that of the lower appellate Court.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Art. 134-B limitation period of 12 years from removal of transferor expired before suit institution, barring trustees' recovery claim; appellants' title upheld via limitation.

holdings.text: The transfers covered by Exts. A-3, A-6 and A-12 fall within Art. 134-B but the suit to challenge them is time-barred.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Although within Art. 134-B, limitation expired due to prior removal of alienor; appellants' prescriptive title upheld indirectly via bar on endowment suit.

anchor.surface_text: Confining ourselves to the first column of Art. 134-B at this stage, the question which we have to decide is does this article permit any distinction to be made between transfers effected by a previous manager on the basis that the property transferred belongs to the religious endowment, and those made by him on the basis that the said property is his own private property ?
ding an execution sale within the meaning of Art. 134B can, with equal justification, be said about introducing words of limitation in the said articl

anchor.surface_text: On that view of the matter, we must hold that the trial Judge and the lower appellate Court were right in decreeing the appellants suit in its entirety. We must accordingly set aside the decree passed by the High Court in regard to the transfers covered by Exts. A-3, A-6 and A-12, and restore that of the lower appellate Court.

Confining ourselves to the first column of Art. 134-B at this stage, the question which we have to decide is does this article permit any distinction to be made between transfers effected by a previous manager on the basis that the property transferred belongs to the religious endowment, and those made by him on the basis that the said property is his own private property ?

On that view of the matter, we must hold that the trial Judge and the lower appellate Court were right in decreeing the appellants suit in its entirety. We must accordingly set aside the decree passed by the High Court in regard to the transfers covered by Exts. A-3, A-6 and A-12, and restore that of the lower appellate Court.

anchor.surface_text: On the findings recorded by the High Court, it is clear that the properties belonged to the temple that they have been transferred by persons who must be deemed to be the previous managers of the temple and that they have been transferred for valuable consideration. The present suit has been brought against respondents 1 to 3 who are appointed trustees of the temple by respondent No. 4 and so, all the ingredients prescribed by the first column of Art. 134-B are satisfied.

On that view of the matter, we must hold that the trial Judge and the lower appellate Court were right in decreeing the appellants suit in its entirety. We must accordingly set aside the decree passed by the High Court in regard to the transfers covered by Exts. A-3, A-6 and A-12, and restore that of the lower appellate Court.
